rev.comment: rrm fair use image being used to depict living person per [[WP:NFCC]]
rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1: â
[[Image:Fighting fire cover.jpg|thumb|250px|Caroline Paul on the cover of ''Fighting Fire'']]
 
'''Caroline Paul''' (born July 29, 1963 in [[New York City]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[writer]] of [[fiction]] and [[nonfiction]]. She was raised in Connecticut (her father was an investment banker, her mother a social worker), and educated in [[journalism]] and [[documentary film]] at [[Stanford University]].<ref name="stanford">[http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/1998/novdec/articles/firefighter.html Stanford University alumnus biography]</ref> She worked as a journalist at Berkeley [[public radio]] station [[KPFA]] before (in 1988) joining the [[San Francisco Fire Department]], as one of the first women hired by the department.<ref name="stanford"/> She worked most of her career on Rescue 2, where she and her crew were responsible for search and rescue in fires. Rescue 2 members were also trained and sent on scuba dive searches, rope and rappelling rescues, surf rescues, confined space rescues, all hazardous material calls, and the most severe train and car wrecks.
'''Caroline Paul''' (born July 29, 1963 in [[New York City]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[writer]] of [[fiction]] and [[nonfiction]]. She was raised in Connecticut (her father was an investment banker, her mother a social worker), and educated in [[journalism]] and [[documentary film]] at [[Stanford University]].<ref name="stanford">[http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/1998/novdec/articles/firefighter.html Stanford University alumnus biography]</ref> She worked as a journalist at Berkeley [[public radio]] station [[KPFA]] before (in 1988) joining the [[San Francisco Fire Department]], as one of the first women hired by the department.<ref name="stanford"/> She worked most of her career on Rescue 2, where she and her crew were responsible for search and rescue in fires. Rescue 2 members were also trained and sent on scuba dive searches, rope and rappelling rescues, surf rescues, confined space rescues, all hazardous material calls, and the most severe train and car wrecks.
